text: John Penrose, the new Minister of State for Northern Ireland, has only been an MP since 2005, yet today entered his third spell of ministerial office, after 2010-12 and 2014-16. The man to to kick out, or bring back, whenever you’re in trouble.

text: There's an unfortunate precedent for Amber Rudd.  David Blunkett resigned as Home Secretary over a scandal in December 2004, only to return as Work & Pensions Secretary a few months later.  He resigned for a second time six months after that

author: MichaelLCrick

text: And David Butler wasn’t just the election night boffin for BBC TV for every general election from 1950 to 1979, but later for ITN & Sky, he was also an election night pundit for Australian TV for many years, and also on Indian TV.
author: MichaelLCrick

text: And David Butler’s Swingometer inspired the Australian equivalent developed by psephologist Malcolm Mackerras: the Mackerras Pendulum
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Read my new book on David Butler & you’ll find DB’s letter of  March 1955 to Grace Wyndham Goldie, & a follow-up a few weeks later about a “speedometer-type device”, precede the 1955 election programme where your small Swingometer was used by Bristol academic Stephen Milne
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Dame Laura Cox tells me that about “half a dozen” MPs are involved in “very very serious” cases of bullying, harassment & sexual harassment in the Commons, & about same number of House staff, what one might call “serial offenders”, & there is “internal awareness” of who they are.

text: The BBC will hold auditions for the new Question Time presenter to replace David Dimbleby this coming Sunday and Monday, at James Allen’s Girls School (JAGS) in Dulwich.  There will be real politicians on the panels and an audience who have been asked to supply questions.

text: It’s interesting Philip May is now supposedly leading the Tories’ phone-Bank operation.  I wonder if he tells the people he calls who is he is?  If so, the answers may not mean much.  And how much of what they say does he pass on to Theresa?

text: It’s worth noting that Darren Grimes delivered an excellent speech - a good mix of humour and serious points.  He would make a bigger impact at Westminster than most MPs.

text: Also appearing with Jeremy Corbyn at tomorrow's event on press freedom is Maxine Peake. I do hope that if Corbyn accuses the media of trivialising politics, nobody mentions that she played John Prescott's mistress Tracy Temple in the ITV drama 'Confessions of a Diary Secretary'.

text: I'm hearing that for tomorrow's speech by Jeremy Corbyn about media freedom, news cameras are banned - "no room" we're told.  Instead the organisers will distribute a transcript and video clips after the event.  Wow! There's a good way to challenge people in power!

text:
For years the wealthy Tapsell resisted hints by local Tory officials that he should stand down in case his death caused an expensive by-election. “How much would a by-election cost the party?” he responded. “Maybe £50,000.” So,
it’s said, he simply wrote out a cheque for £50,000.

text: Cameron, Blair and Ramsay Macdonald hadn't been ministers before being PM, but were MPs longer than Leadsom & led their parties for years

text: Andrea Leadsom has been an MP 6 years; junior minister 2 years. She'd be least politically experienced PM since William Pitt the Younger
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Also Leadsom would become PM without having even been a Privy Councillor.  Who was the last example of that?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Good point. She would be the most inexperienced PM in Commons service since who? Cameron had been an MP 9 years; Major, 11.
author: MichaelLCrick

text: If so, it's happening very slowly.
author: MichaelLCrick

text: That doesn't mean all their MPs would do likewise

text: I agree, which would mean May becomes PM in the next 10 days

text: Note to Radio 4 presenters: it's the European Championship (singular). Why do you make it Championships (plural)? There's only one of them
author: MichaelLCrick

text: So demonstrators of more value than ordinary folk? An elite perhaps?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Indeed. But is one man one vote outdated? One demonstrator ten votes maybe, & just one for people who, as you say, sit on arse?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: So they're a kind of elite then?  More important than ordinary apathetic voters, do you think?  Do they deserve extra votes?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: So demonstrators are a kind of elite are they? Should they get 10 votes in elections say, & everyone else just one?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Crikey.  Tell us about the even less probably routes. A time machine? Nuclear war? Magic?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: Maybe. Or free time. How much more weight do marchers get? Twice? 10 times? 20?
author: MichaelLCrick

text: For true democrats should the views of somebody who went on a public demonstration carry more weight than somebody who didn't?  Discuss
author: MichaelLCrick

text: You may well be right. I can't spend the weekend tallying names.
